_children.body:
The products $$\mathrm{A}$$ and $$\mathrm{B}$$ obtained in the following reactions, respectively, are

$$\begin{aligned} & 3 \mathrm{ROH}+\mathrm{PCl}_3 \rightarrow 3 \mathrm{RCl}+\mathrm{A} \\ & \mathrm{ROH}+\mathrm{PCl}_5 \rightarrow \mathrm{RCl}+\mathrm{HCl}+\mathrm{B} \end{aligned}$$
_children.explanation:
Let's analyze the given reactions and determine the products $$\mathrm{A}$$ and $$\mathrm{B}$$.

Reaction with PCl3:

When an alcohol ($$\mathrm{ROH}$$) reacts with phosphorus trichloride ($$\mathrm{PCl}_3$$), the hydroxyl group ($$\mathrm{OH}$$) of the alcohol is replaced by a chloro group ($$\mathrm{Cl}$$), resulting in the formation of an alkyl chloride ($$\mathrm{RCl}$$). Additionally, the reaction produces phosphorous acid as a byproduct. This can be represented as:

$$3 \mathrm{ROH} + \mathrm{PCl}_3 \rightarrow 3 \mathrm{RCl} + \mathrm{H}_3\mathrm{PO}_3$$

Here, $$\mathrm{A}$$ is $$\mathrm{H}_3\mathrm{PO}_3$$ (phosphorous acid).

Reaction with PCl5:

When an alcohol reacts with phosphorus pentachloride ($$\mathrm{PCl}_5$$), it also replaces the hydroxyl group with a chloro group. The reaction differs slightly in the byproducts; phosphorus oxychloride ($$\mathrm{POCl}_3$$) and hydrogen chloride ($$\mathrm{HCl}$$) are produced:

$$\mathrm{ROH} + \mathrm{PCl}_5 \rightarrow \mathrm{RCl} + \mathrm{HCl} + \mathrm{POCl}_3$$

Here, $$\mathrm{B}$$ is $$\mathrm{POCl}_3$$ (phosphorus oxychloride).

Thus, in the reactions provided:

  • $$\mathrm{A} = \mathrm{H}_3\mathrm{PO}_3$$
  • $$\mathrm{B} = \mathrm{POCl}_3$$

Matching these findings against the provided options, we see that Option D correctly identifies $$\mathrm{A}$$ as $$\mathrm{H}_3\mathrm{PO}_3$$ and $$\mathrm{B}$$ as $$\mathrm{POCl}_3$$:

Option D: $$\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{PO}_3$$ and $$\mathrm{POCl}_3$$

This is the correct answer.

_children.body:
Given below are two statements:

Statement I : In Lucas test, primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols are distinguished on the basis of their reactivity with conc. HCl + ZnCl2, known as Lucas Reagent.

Statement II : Primary alcohols are most reactive and immediately produce turbidity at room temperature on reaction with Lucas Reagent.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:

options.value: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct

_children.explanation:
Primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols can be differentiated by their reaction with (HCl + anhy ZnCl2) Lucas reagent

$$\bullet$$ 3$$^\circ$$ alcohol $$\buildrel {ZnC{l_2} + HCl} \over \longrightarrow $$ Immediate turbidity at room temperature

$$\bullet$$ 2$$^\circ$$ alcohol $$\buildrel {ZnC{l_2} + HCl} \over \longrightarrow $$ Turbidity after 5 minutes at room temperature

$$\bullet$$ 1$$^\circ$$ alcohol $$\buildrel {ZnC{l_2} + HCl} \over \longrightarrow $$ Do not gives turbidity at room temperature

_children.body: Which of the following compounds can be used as antifreeze in automobile radiators?
_children.explanation: Glycol is used as an antifreeze in automobiles.

_children.body: Given are cyclohexanol (I), acetic acid (II), 2, 4, 6-trinitrophenol (III) and phenol (IV). In these the order of decreasing acidic character will be
_children.explanation:
As we know that phenols and carboxylic acids are more acidic than aliphatic alcohols thus cyclohexanol is least acidic.

On the other hand III is more acidic than IV because of the presence of three highly electron with drawing NO2 groups on the benzene ring which makes the OH bond extremely polarized. This facilitates the release of H+.

In acetic acid the electron withdrawing $$ - \mathop C\limits_| = O$$

group polarizes the O-H bond and increases the acid strength.

Thus, acetic acid is more acidic than phenol or cyclohexanol.

Thus, the order of acidic strength will be

III > II > IV > I

_children.body:
Among the following four compounds
(i)  Phenol
(ii)  Methyl phenol
(iii)  Meta-nitrophenol
(iv)  Para-nitrophenol

The acidity order is
_children.explanation:
In phenols, the presence of electron releasing groups decrease the acidity, whereas presence of electron withdrawing groups increase the acidity, compared to phenol.

Among the meta and para-nitrophenols, the latter is more acidic as the presence of –NO2 group at para position stabilises the phenoxide ion to a greater extent than when it is present at meta position. Thus, correct order of acidity is :

(iv) > (iii) > (i) > (ii)

_children.body: The general molecular formula, which represents the homologous series of alkanols is
_children.explanation:
All alcohols follow the general formula as
C<sub>n</sub>H<sub>2n+2</sub>O.

_children.body: The general molecular formula, which represents the homologous series of alkanols is
_children.explanation:
General molecular formula of alkanols is

CnH2n+2O or CnH2n+1OH

_children.body: Which one of the following will not form a yellow precipitate on heating with an alkaline solution of iodine?
_children.explanation:
Formation of a yellow precipitate on heating
a compound with an alkaline solution of iodine is
known as iodoform reaction. Methyl alcohol does
not respond to this test. Iodoform test is exhibited
by ethyl alcohol, acetaldehyde, acetone, methyl
ketones and those alcohols which possess
CH<sub>3</sub>CH(OH) – group.

_children.body: Which of the following is correct?

options.value: On reduction, any aldehyde gives secondary alcohol.
Reaction of vegetable oil with H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> gives glycerine
Alcoholic iodine with NaOH gives iodoform.
Sucrose on reaction with NaCl gives invert sugar.

_children.explanation:
C2H5OH + 4I2 + NaOH $$ \to $$

CHI3 + NaI + HCOONa + H2O

Iodoform is a pale yellow solid which crystallises in hexagonal plates.
